content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

As a human player, I would choose strategy R for this game. Here is my reasoning:

If both players consistently pick the same strategy (R or B), they will earn 45$ or 12$ per round respectively. However, if one player switches their strategy during the game, they can gain an advantage. Since we don't know our opponent's strategy and the game has 75 rounds, it's difficult to predict the optimal moment to switch.

To minimize the risk of losing, it is best to choose a strategy that earns a higher payoff when the opponent picks the opposite choice. In this case, R yields 45$ when the opponent chooses B and only 12$ when they also pick R. On the other hand, choosing B yields 42$ if the opponent picks R and 12$ when they also choose B. As a result, choosing R gives us the potential for a higher payoff in more situations.

Additionally, since we are playing 75 rounds of this game, it is likely that the average payoff will approach the expected value of each strategy. The expected value of strategy R is 3 times the expected value of strategy B, as R yields 33$ (45 - 12) on average per round when the opponent chooses B, while B only yields 4$ (12 - 8) on average per round when the opponent chooses R.

Therefore, I would choose strategy R in this game. {R}
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 42$. Please play the next round.

In this scenario, my opponent chose B while I chose R. As a result, I received 0$ and they earned 42$.

However, since we are playing multiple rounds of the game, it would not be wise to stick with the same strategy based on just one outcome. Instead, I will try to adapt my strategy according to the information gathered from the previous round. Since my opponent chose B in the last round, I can infer that they may have a tendency to choose B more often.

Given that R yields a higher payoff when the opponent chooses B (45$ vs 12$), it would be rational to continue choosing R in this game, as it gives me the potential for a higher average payoff over multiple rounds. Additionally, since my opponent earned 42$ in the last round by choosing B while I chose R, they may be more likely to switch their strategy in the next round.

By choosing R again, I can capitalize on this potential change in strategy by the opponent and possibly earn 45$ if they switch to R, or at least maintain my 12$ payoff if they stick with B.

So, I would choose R for the next round as well. {R}
You chose R. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 45$. Your opponent's payoff is 45$. Please play the next round.

In this scenario, both my opponent and I chose R in the previous round. As a result, we both earned 45$ each.

Since we both chose the same strategy in the last round, it is unclear whether this was a coincidence or an indication of a consistent strategy by the opponent. However, since we are playing multiple rounds of the game, I will continue to adapt my strategy based on the available information.

In this case, as R yields the highest payoff when both players choose the same strategy (45$), it would be rational to stick with strategy R for now, as it ensures that I maintain a high average payoff over multiple rounds. Additionally, since we have just seen the opponent also choosing R, there is no clear advantage in switching strategies at this point.

However, I should keep observing the opponent's choices and adapt my strategy if needed to maximize my potential earnings.
